awd_titl_txt: Ultraviolet and Visible Spectroscopy at McMurdo Station
awd_abstract_narration: This project is to study the chemistry of the antarctic                         stratosphere with a focus on those chemical constituents that are               related to the annual springtime depletion of ozone, known as the               ozone hole.  Visible and near ultraviolet spectroscopy will be                  used to measure the total column abundances of nitrogen dioxide,                symmetrical chlorine dioxide, nitrogen trioxide and bromine                     monoxide above McMurdo, Antarctica.  The variation of the diurnal               variation of these chemicals is of particular value in                          understanding the photochemical processes that cause the ozone                  hole.  In addition, a novel technique that uses the moon as a                   light source during times of sunrise and sunset will allow the                  measurement of vertical profiles and also the rate of photolysis                of fast reacting species.                                                       This research is funded by the NOAA Aeronomy Laboratory with                    logistical support provided by NSF/DPP.
